IN-OFFICE  vs  REMOTE LEGAL INTERNSHIPSYou applied for a virtual remote internship. You got selected.You updated your LinkedIn.But wait… Is a remote legal internship actually worth it?Will recruiters value it?Will you learn real skills?Orwill you just become an email-forwarding intern?Here's the verdict:1⃣ Learning curve: Hands-on work vs. Screen work📍 In-office internship = Real-world exposure. You watch senior lawyers argue in court, draft real contracts, and interact with clients. 📍 Remote internship = Good for research & drafting. But you miss out on the action. No court visits, no last-minute client calls.✅ Example: A litigation intern working in an office learns court procedures.A remote intern?They research case laws but never see them argued in real time.💡If you want practical legal skills, in-office wins. If you love research & writing, remote works.2⃣ Networking: Coffee chats vs. Cold Emails📍 In-office internship = You interact with seniors, learn from casual conversations, and build real relationships. 📍 Remote internship = You connect via emails & Zoom.It’s harder to make a lasting impression.✅ Example: An intern at a corporate firm grabs coffee with a partner, gets career advice, and later, a job referral.A remote intern?Sends a “Thank you for the opportunity” email and gets… seen-zoned.💡 Want strong industry connections? In-office internships are gold.3⃣ Work-life balance: Hustle vs. Flexibility📍 In-office internship = Fixed schedule. Long hours. Commuting stress. 📍 Remote internship = Work from anywhere. More control over time.✅ Example: A remote intern can attend classes and work at night. An in-office intern?Running from courtrooms to college like a legal Usain Bolt.💡 If you need flexibility, remote internships win. If you want the real law firm experience, in-office is unbeatable.4⃣ CV value: "Interned" vs. "Actually worked"📍 In-office internships = More credibility. Lawyers trust work done in a law firm setting. 📍 Remote internships = Skeptical recruiters.Did you really work, or just edit PDFs?✅ Example: A hiring partner sees two CVs:One intern worked physically in a top-tier firm.One intern remotely with a legal blog.Who gets the callback?You know the answer. 😉💡 Want a CV that stands out? In-office internships have more weight.5⃣ Which one teaches you more? 📍Remote internships are great for research, writing, and learning at your own pace. 📍 In-office internships teach real legal work—drafting, client handling, and actual practice.✅ Example:A litigation intern in court learns how judges react to arguments.A remote intern reads judgments but never sees them applied.💡 If you want to become a lawyer, in-office internships will teach you more.🎯 Final advice?📌 If you’re in 1st or 2nd year, remote internships help build skills. 📌 If you’re in 3rd year or beyond, prioritize in-office internships.Real exposure > Virtual learning.hashtag#law

Post Content:
Core JavaDay-19Encapsulation:---------------------Encapsulation is a process of making variables are private and accessing through methods public those are getters and setters.-If we declare all variables are private, then it is tightly coupled class.-If we declare any one variable is not private, then it is loosely coupled class.-setters-Always declare return type as void.-getters-Always declare its respective return type and does't have any parameter.Benefits of Encapsulation:1. Data Hiding: Encapsulation protects the data from unauthorized access.2.Increased Flexibility: It allows the internal implementation to be changed without affecting the external code.3.Improved Maintainability:  It helps in maintaining the code by keeping the data private and providing controlled access to modify it. 4.Reusability:  Encapsulated code is easier to reuse in other parts of the application.5.Testing: Encapsulated units can be tested independently.BILLA HEMANTH10000 Coders

🚀 Bare-Metal I2C LCD Project with STM32G071RBRecently completed a project interfacing a 16x2 I2C LCD (address: 0x27) with the STM32G071RB microcontroller — fully implemented using bare-metal C, without relying on HAL or any abstraction layers.🛠️ Key Technical Details:1.MCU: STM32G071RB2.I2C1 configured on PB8 (SCL) and PB9 (SDA) using Alternate Function6(AF6)3.LCD controlled via PCF8574 I/O expander4.Printed “Prathmesh” using register-level code5.Developed in STM32CubeIDE, using only core device headers🎯 Why bare-metal? This approach provides better control, efficiency, and deep understanding of hardware behavior — a crucial skill for low-level embedded systems development.💡 This project reinforced concepts like:Manual I2C protocol implementationGPIO alternate function mappingBitwise register manipulationDebugging embedded interfaces without abstraction📍Next goal: Extend this by adding sensors hashtag#EmbeddedSystems hashtag#STM32 hashtag#I2C hashtag#LCD hashtag#FirmwareDevelopment hashtag#EmbeddedC hashtag#Microcontrollers

Data Hiding: Encapsulation protects the data from unauthorized access.2.Increased Flexibility: It allows the internal implementation to be changed without affecting the external code.3.Improved Maintainability:  It helps in maintaining the code by keeping the data private and providing controlled access to modify it. 4.Reusability:  Encapsulated code is easier to reuse in other parts of the application.5.Testing: Encapsulated units can be tested independently.BILLA HEMANTH10000 Coders

🚀 Bare-Metal I2C LCD Project with STM32G071RBRecently completed a project interfacing a 16x2 I2C LCD (address: 0x27) with the STM32G071RB microcontroller — fully implemented using bare-metal C, without relying on HAL or any abstraction layers.🛠️ Key Technical Details:1.MCU: STM32G071RB2.I2C1 configured on PB8 (SCL) and PB9 (SDA) using Alternate Function6(AF6)3.LCD controlled via PCF8574 I/O expander4.Printed “Prathmesh” using register-level code5.Developed in STM32CubeIDE, using only core device headers🎯 Why bare-metal? This approach provides better control, efficiency, and deep understanding of hardware behavior — a crucial skill for low-level embedded systems development.💡 This project reinforced concepts like:Manual I2C protocol implementationGPIO alternate function mappingBitwise register manipulationDebugging embedded interfaces without abstraction📍Next goal: Extend this by adding sensors hashtag#EmbeddedSystems hashtag#STM32 hashtag#I2C hashtag#LCD hashtag#FirmwareDevelopment hashtag#EmbeddedC hashtag#Microcontrollers

“Are you even working if you’re not commuting 2 hours a day and eating sad sandwiches in meetings that could’ve been emails?” 😒That used to be the unspoken (and sometimes spoken) rule in the corporate world.So….Let’s rewind a bit!A few years ago, I was deep in the 9-to-5 grind. I had the desk. The ID Card. The Friday pizza parties. The “you’re on mute” calls.But also—the burnout, the lack of flexibility, and the quiet dread of Monday mornings.Remote work? That was considered a “perk,” not a viable lifestyle.It was the forbidden fruit in the orchard of productivity myths.So, I did something wild…I quit.🙃First, I dipped my toes into freelancing—scary but liberating. Then, I cannonballed into starting my own business!SynapseITSolutions !No map. Just Wi-Fi and willpower.Suddenly, I wasn’t just working remotely…I WAS LIVING INTENTIONALLY!I had control.I picked my hours, my clients, my chai breaks. I replaced commutes with creativity, and burnout with balance.And guess what?I didn’t just survive—I thrived. 😇Now here’s the kicker: the same companies that once side-eyed remote work?They’re embracing it.They’ve seen the numbers. The productivity. The morale boost. The talent retention.Turns out, trusting your team actually works. Who knew? 😉One of my favorite moments was when a former manager messaged me:“I used to think remote workers were just watching Netflix all day. Now I’m one of them—and I’ve never been more productive.”Look, remote vs hybrid vs in-office isn’t a one-size-fits-all debate.But it is about choice. Autonomy. Trust. And reimagining what work can look like!To everyone who’s made the leap, is dreaming of it, or just questioning the status quo—you’re not alone.Because work shouldn’t be a place….It should be a feeling!😇hashtag#RemoteWork hashtag#HybridWork hashtag#WorkLifeBalance hashtag#EntrepreneurLife hashtag#FreelanceLife hashtag#StartUpLife

IN-OFFICE  vs  REMOTE LEGAL INTERNSHIPSYou applied for a virtual remote internship. You got selected.You updated your LinkedIn.But wait… Is a remote legal internship actually worth it?Will recruiters value it?Will you learn real skills?Orwill you just become an email-forwarding intern?Here's the verdict:1⃣ Learning curve: Hands-on work vs. Screen work📍 In-office internship = Real-world exposure. You watch senior lawyers argue in court, draft real contracts, and interact with clients. 📍 Remote internship = Good for research & drafting. But you miss out on the action. No court visits, no last-minute client calls.✅ Example: A litigation intern working in an office learns court procedures.A remote intern?They research case laws but never see them argued in real time.💡If you want practical legal skills, in-office wins. If you love research & writing, remote works.2⃣ Networking: Coffee chats vs. Cold Emails📍 In-office internship = You interact with seniors, learn from casual conversations, and build real relationships. 📍 Remote internship = You connect via emails & Zoom.It’s harder to make a lasting impression.✅ Example: An intern at a corporate firm grabs coffee with a partner, gets career advice, and later, a job referral.A remote intern?Sends a “Thank you for the opportunity” email and gets… seen-zoned.💡 Want strong industry connections? In-office internships are gold.3⃣ Work-life balance: Hustle vs. Flexibility📍 In-office internship = Fixed schedule. Long hours. Commuting stress. 📍 Remote internship = Work from anywhere. More control over time.✅ Example: A remote intern can attend classes and work at night. An in-office intern?Running from courtrooms to college like a legal Usain Bolt.💡 If you need flexibility, remote internships win. If you want the real law firm experience, in-office is unbeatable.4⃣ CV value: "Interned" vs. "Actually worked"📍 In-office internships = More credibility. Lawyers trust work done in a law firm setting. 📍 Remote internships = Skeptical recruiters.Did you really work, or just edit PDFs?✅ Example: A hiring partner sees two CVs:One intern worked physically in a top-tier firm.One intern remotely with a legal blog.Who gets the callback?You know the answer. 😉💡 Want a CV that stands out? In-office internships have more weight.5⃣ Which one teaches you more? 📍Remote internships are great for research, writing, and learning at your own pace. 📍 In-office internships teach real legal work—drafting, client handling, and actual practice.✅ Example:A litigation intern in court learns how judges react to arguments.A remote intern reads judgments but never sees them applied.💡 If you want to become a lawyer, in-office internships will teach you more.🎯 Final advice?📌 If you’re in 1st or 2nd year, remote internships help build skills. 📌 If you’re in 3rd year or beyond, prioritize in-office internships.Real exposure > Virtual learning.hashtag#law

🏴‍☠️ Ο Initial Access Broker "𝗧𝗼𝘆𝗠𝗮𝗸𝗲𝗿" με οικονομικά κίνητρα διεισδύει σε έναν οργανισμό υποδομής κρίσιμης σημασίας χρησιμοποιώντας την κερκόπορτα 𝗟𝗔𝗚𝗧𝗢𝗬, παραχωρώντας αργότερα πρόσβαση στην ομάδα ληστρικού λογισμικού 𝗖𝗮𝗰𝘁𝘂𝘀. Η επίθεση κορυφώθηκε με διπλό εκβιασμό και ανάπτυξη ransomware χρησιμοποιώντας έναν συνδυασμό κλοπής διαπιστευτηρίων, προσαρμοσμένων εμφυτευμάτων και εργαλείων απομακρυσμένου διαχειριστή.🤑 Οι Initial Access Brokers είναι συχνά το πρώτο βήμα σε μια επιτυχημένη καμπάνια για έναν παράγοντα απειλής. Οι μεσίτες πρόσβασης εργάζονται σε ένα περιβάλλον, συλλέγουν σχετικά δεδομένα και στη συνέχεια πωλούν αυτές τις πληροφορίες σε έναν παράγοντα απειλής για περαιτέρω συμβιβασμό. IN-OFFICE  vs  REMOTE LEGAL INTERNSHIPSYou applied for a virtual remote internship. You got selected.You updated your LinkedIn.But wait… Is a remote legal internship actually worth it?Will recruiters value it?Will you learn real skills?Orwill you just become an email-forwarding intern?Here's the verdict:1⃣ Learning curve: Hands-on work vs. Screen work📍 In-office internship = Real-world exposure. You watch senior lawyers argue in court, draft real contracts, and interact with clients. 📍 Remote internship = Good for research & drafting. But you miss out on the action. No court visits, no last-minute client calls.✅ Example: A litigation intern working in an office learns court procedures.A remote intern?They research case laws but never see them argued in real time.💡If you want practical legal skills, in-office wins. If you love research & writing, remote works.2⃣ Networking: Coffee chats vs. Cold Emails📍 In-office internship = You interact with seniors, learn from casual conversations, and build real relationships. 📍 Remote internship = You connect via emails & Zoom.It’s harder to make a lasting impression.✅ Example: An intern at a corporate firm grabs coffee with a partner, gets career advice, and later, a job referral.A remote intern?Sends a “Thank you for the opportunity” email and gets… seen-zoned.💡 Want strong industry connections? In-office internships are gold.3⃣ Work-life balance: Hustle vs. Flexibility📍 In-office internship = Fixed schedule. Long hours. Commuting stress. 📍 Remote internship = Work from anywhere. More control over time.✅ Example: A remote intern can attend classes and work at night. An in-office intern?Running from courtrooms to college like a legal Usain Bolt.💡 If you need flexibility, remote internships win. If you want the real law firm experience, in-office is unbeatable.4⃣ CV value: "Interned" vs. "Actually worked"📍 In-office internships = More credibility. Lawyers trust work done in a law firm setting. 📍 Remote internships = Skeptical recruiters.Did you really work, or just edit PDFs?✅ Example: A hiring partner sees two CVs:One intern worked physically in a top-tier firm.One intern remotely with a legal blog.Who gets the callback?You know the answer. 😉💡 Want a CV that stands out? In-office internships have more weight.5⃣ Which one teaches you more? 📍Remote internships are great for research, writing, and learning at your own pace. 📍 In-office internships teach real legal work—drafting, client handling, and actual practice.✅ Example:A litigation intern in court learns how judges react to arguments.A remote intern reads judgments but never sees them applied.💡 If you want to become a lawyer, in-office internships will teach you more.🎯 Final advice?📌 If you’re in 1st or 2nd year, remote internships help build skills. 📌 If you’re in 3rd year or beyond, prioritize in-office internships.Real exposure > Virtual learning.hashtag#law

Core JavaDay-19Encapsulation:---------------------Encapsulation is a process of making variables are private and accessing through methods public those are getters and setters.-If we declare all variables are private, then it is tightly coupled class.-If we declare any one variable is not private, then it is loosely coupled class.-setters-Always declare return type as void.-getters-Always declare its respective return type and does't have any parameter.Benefits of Encapsulation:1. Data Hiding: Encapsulation protects the data from unauthorized access.2.Increased Flexibility: It allows the internal implementation to be changed without affecting the external code.3.Improved Maintainability:  It helps in maintaining the code by keeping the data private and providing controlled access to modify it. 4.Reusability:  Encapsulated code is easier to reuse in other parts of the application.5.Testing: Encapsulated units can be tested independently.BILLA HEMANTH10000 Coders

🚀 Bare-Metal I2C LCD Project with STM32G071RBRecently completed a project interfacing a 16x2 I2C LCD (address: 0x27) with the STM32G071RB microcontroller — fully implemented using bare-metal C, without relying on HAL or any abstraction layers.🛠️ Key Technical Details:1.MCU: STM32G071RB2.I2C1 configured on PB8 (SCL) and PB9 (SDA) using Alternate Function6(AF6)3.LCD controlled via PCF8574 I/O expander4.Printed “Prathmesh” using register-level code5.Developed in STM32CubeIDE, using only core device headers🎯 Why bare-metal? This approach provides better control, efficiency, and deep understanding of hardware behavior — a crucial skill for low-level embedded systems development.💡 This project reinforced concepts like:Manual I2C protocol implementationGPIO alternate function mappingBitwise register manipulationDebugging embedded interfaces without abstraction📍Next goal: Extend this by adding sensors hashtag#EmbeddedSystems hashtag#STM32 hashtag#I2C hashtag#LCD hashtag#FirmwareDevelopment hashtag#EmbeddedC hashtag#Microcontrollers

“Are you even working if you’re not commuting 2 hours a day and eating sad sandwiches in meetings that could’ve been emails?” 😒That used to be the unspoken (and sometimes spoken) rule in the corporate world.So….Let’s rewind a bit!A few years ago, I was deep in the 9-to-5 grind. I had the desk. The ID Card. The Friday pizza parties. The “you’re on mute” calls.But also—the burnout, the lack of flexibility, and the quiet dread of Monday mornings.Remote work? That was considered a “perk,” not a viable lifestyle.It was the forbidden fruit in the orchard of productivity myths.So, I did something wild…I quit.🙃First, I dipped my toes into freelancing—scary but liberating. Then, I cannonballed into starting my own business!SynapseITSolutions !No map. Just Wi-Fi and willpower.Suddenly, I wasn’t just working remotely…I WAS LIVING INTENTIONALLY!I had control.I picked my hours, my clients, my chai breaks. I replaced commutes with creativity, and burnout with balance.And guess what?I didn’t just survive—I thrived. 😇Now here’s the kicker: the same companies that once side-eyed remote work?They’re embracing it.They’ve seen the numbers. The productivity. The morale boost. The talent retention.Turns out, trusting your team actually works. Who knew? 😉One of my favorite moments was when a former manager messaged me:“I used to think remote workers were just watching Netflix all day. Now I’m one of them—and I’ve never been more productive.”Look, remote vs hybrid vs in-office isn’t a one-size-fits-all debate.But it is about choice. Autonomy. Trust. And reimagining what work can look like!To everyone who’s made the leap, is dreaming of it, or just questioning the status quo—you’re not alone.Because work shouldn’t be a place….It should be a feeling!😇hashtag#RemoteWork hashtag#HybridWork hashtag#WorkLifeBalance hashtag#EntrepreneurLife hashtag#FreelanceLife hashtag#StartUpLife

🚀 Day 04 of my hashtag#100DaysOfCUDA challenge! 🚀1)Today I tackled a parallel partial-sum (inclusive scan) kernel on the GPU:Summed two input elements per thread (input[idx] + input[idx+blockDim.x]) into shared memory for coalesced loads.2)Added guarded-load logic so threads past the array end read zero, avoiding out-of-bounds errors.3) Laid out a tree-based inclusive scan in shared memory, doing O(log blockSize) strides with __syncthreads() for each step.4) Computed gridSize = (N + 2*blockSize – 1)/(2*blockSize) so every element is processed when each block handles 2×blockSize inputs.5)Wrapped all CUDA API calls in a CUDA_CHECK macro to catch and report errors immediately.🔹 Key takeawaysIn-place prefix sum: Implemented a scalable tree-based scan pattern in shared memory.Memory coalescing: Two-element threads maximize bandwidth by loading contiguous data.Bounds safety: Guarded-load idioms ensure correctness when N isn’t a multiple of 2×blockSize.Grid-block sizing: 2 elements per thread halves the number of required blocks, improving occupancy.📂 Check out the code and follow along: 👉 https://lnkd.in/dwkvia42Would love your feedback: 💬 Any tips for further optimizing scan kernels? 👍 Drop a like if you enjoy these daily deep dives!hashtag#CUDA hashtag#GPUProgramming hashtag#ParallelComputing hashtag#PrefixSum hashtag#SharedMemory hashtag#PMPP hashtag#100DaysOfCUDA

IN-OFFICE  vs  REMOTE LEGAL INTERNSHIPSYou applied for a virtual remote internship. You got selected.You updated your LinkedIn.But wait… Is a remote legal internship actually worth it?Will recruiters value it?Will you learn real skills?Orwill you just become an email-forwarding intern?Here's the verdict:1⃣ Learning curve: Hands-on work vs. Screen work📍 In-office internship = Real-world exposure. You watch senior lawyers argue in court, draft real contracts, and interact with clients. 📍 Remote internship = Good for research & drafting. But you miss out on the action. No court visits, no last-minute client calls.✅ Example: A litigation intern working in an office learns court procedures.A remote intern?They research case laws but never see them argued in real time.💡If you want practical legal skills, in-office wins. If you love research & writing, remote works.2⃣ Networking: Coffee chats vs. Cold Emails📍 In-office internship = You interact with seniors, learn from casual conversations, and build real relationships. 📍 Remote internship = You connect via emails & Zoom.It’s harder to make a lasting impression.✅ Example: An intern at a corporate firm grabs coffee with a partner, gets career advice, and later, a job referral.A remote intern?Sends a “Thank you for the opportunity” email and gets… seen-zoned.💡 Want strong industry connections? In-office internships are gold.3⃣ Work-life balance: Hustle vs. Flexibility📍 In-office internship = Fixed schedule. Long hours. Commuting stress. 📍 Remote internship = Work from anywhere. More control over time.✅ Example: A remote intern can attend classes and work at night. An in-office intern?Running from courtrooms to college like a legal Usain Bolt.💡 If you need flexibility, remote internships win. If you want the real law firm experience, in-office is unbeatable.4⃣ CV value: "Interned" vs. "Actually worked"📍 In-office internships = More credibility. Lawyers trust work done in a law firm setting. 📍 Remote internships = Skeptical recruiters.Did you really work, or just edit PDFs?✅ Example: A hiring partner sees two CVs:One intern worked physically in a top-tier firm.One intern remotely with a legal blog.Who gets the callback?You know the answer. 😉💡 Want a CV that stands out? In-office internships have more weight.5⃣ Which one teaches you more? 📍Remote internships are great for research, writing, and learning at your own pace. 📍 In-office internships teach real legal work—drafting, client handling, and actual practice.✅ Example:A litigation intern in court learns how judges react to arguments.A remote intern reads judgments but never sees them applied.💡 If you want to become a lawyer, in-office internships will teach you more.🎯 Final advice?📌 If you’re in 1st or 2nd year, remote internships help build skills. 📌 If you’re in 3rd year or beyond, prioritize in-office internships.Real exposure > Virtual learning.hashtag#law

Core JavaDay-19Encapsulation:---------------------Encapsulation is a process of making variables are private and accessing through methods public those are getters and setters.-If we declare all variables are private, then it is tightly coupled class.-If we declare any one variable is not private, then it is loosely coupled class.-setters-Always declare return type as void.-getters-Always declare its respective return type and does't have any parameter.Benefits of Encapsulation:1. Data Hiding: Encapsulation protects the data from unauthorized access.2.Increased Flexibility: It allows the internal implementation to be changed without affecting the external code.3.Improved Maintainability:  It helps in maintaining the code by keeping the data private and providing controlled access to modify it. 4.Reusability:  Encapsulated code is easier to reuse in other parts of the application.5.Testing: Encapsulated units can be tested independently.BILLA HEMANTH10000 Coders

🚀 Bare-Metal I2C LCD Project with STM32G071RBRecently completed a project interfacing a 16x2 I2C LCD (address: 0x27) with the STM32G071RB microcontroller — fully implemented using bare-metal C, without relying on HAL or any abstraction layers.🛠️ Key Technical Details:1.MCU: STM32G071RB2.I2C1 configured on PB8 (SCL) and PB9 (SDA) using Alternate Function6(AF6)3.LCD controlled via PCF8574 I/O expander4.Printed “Prathmesh” using register-level code5.Developed in STM32CubeIDE, using only core device headers🎯 Why bare-metal? This approach provides better control, efficiency, and deep understanding of hardware behavior — a crucial skill for low-level embedded systems development.💡 This project reinforced concepts like:Manual I2C protocol implementationGPIO alternate function mappingBitwise register manipulationDebugging embedded interfaces without abstraction📍Next goal: Extend this by adding sensors hashtag#EmbeddedSystems hashtag#STM32 hashtag#I2C hashtag#LCD hashtag#FirmwareDevelopment hashtag#EmbeddedC hashtag#Microcontrollers

“Are you even working if you’re not commuting 2 hours a day and eating sad sandwiches in meetings that could’ve been emails?” 😒That used to be the unspoken (and sometimes spoken) rule in the corporate world.So….Let’s rewind a bit!A few years ago, I was deep in the 9-to-5 grind. I had the desk. The ID Card. The Friday pizza parties. The “you’re on mute” calls.But also—the burnout, the lack of flexibility, and the quiet dread of Monday mornings.Remote work? That was considered a “perk,” not a viable lifestyle.It was the forbidden fruit in the orchard of productivity myths.So, I did something wild…I quit.🙃First, I dipped my toes into freelancing—scary but liberating. Then, I cannonballed into starting my own business!SynapseITSolutions !No map. Just Wi-Fi and willpower.Suddenly, I wasn’t just working remotely…I WAS LIVING INTENTIONALLY!I had control.I picked my hours, my clients, my chai breaks. I replaced commutes with creativity, and burnout with balance.And guess what?I didn’t just survive—I thrived. 😇Now here’s the kicker: the same companies that once side-eyed remote work?They’re embracing it.They’ve seen the numbers. The productivity. The morale boost. The talent retention.Turns out, trusting your team actually works. Who knew? 😉One of my favorite moments was when a former manager messaged me:“I used to think remote workers were just watching Netflix all day. Now I’m one of them—and I’ve never been more productive.”Look, remote vs hybrid vs in-office isn’t a one-size-fits-all debate.But it is about choice. Autonomy. Trust. And reimagining what work can look like!To everyone who’s made the leap, is dreaming of it, or just questioning the status quo—you’re not alone.Because work shouldn’t be a place….It should be a feeling!😇hashtag#RemoteWork hashtag#HybridWork hashtag#WorkLifeBalance hashtag#EntrepreneurLife hashtag#FreelanceLife hashtag#StartUpLife

🏴‍☠️ Ο Initial Access Broker "𝗧𝗼𝘆𝗠𝗮𝗸𝗲𝗿" με οικονομικά κίνητρα διεισδύει σε έναν οργανισμό υποδομής κρίσιμης σημασίας χρησιμοποιώντας την κερκόπορτα 𝗟𝗔𝗚𝗧𝗢𝗬, παραχωρώντας αργότερα πρόσβαση στην ομάδα ληστρικού λογισμικού 𝗖𝗮𝗰𝘁𝘂𝘀. Η επίθεση κορυφώθηκε με διπλό εκβιασμό και ανάπτυξη ransomware χρησιμοποιώντας έναν συνδυασμό κλοπής διαπιστευτηρίων, προσαρμοσμένων εμφυτευμάτων και εργαλείων απομακρυσμένου διαχειριστή.🤑 Οι Initial Access Brokers είναι συχνά το πρώτο βήμα σε μια επιτυχημένη καμπάνια για έναν παράγοντα απειλής. Οι μεσίτες πρόσβασης εργάζονται σε ένα περιβάλλον, συλλέγουν σχετικά δεδομένα και στη συνέχεια πωλούν αυτές τις πληροφορίες σε έναν παράγοντα απειλής για περαιτέρω συμβιβασμό. Ερευνητές στο Cisco Talos ανέφεραν για ένα IAB που ονομάζεται ToyMaker και παρείχαν τεχνικές λεπτομέρειες σχετικά με το προσαρμοσμένο εμφύτευμά τους που ονομάζεται LAGTOY. Η αναφορά κοινοποιεί επίσης λεπτομέρειες μιας συγκεκριμένης καμπάνιας στην οποία η ToyMaker παρείχε πρόσβαση στην ομάδα ransomware Cactus.☠️ Κακόβουλος Παράγων: ToyMaker, cactus Ransomware Group☣️ Κακόβουλο Λογισμικό: LAGTOY⚡Σοβαρότις: Υψηλή🤢 Αντίκτυπο: Κλοπή διαπιστευτηρίων, συμβιβασμός δικτύου, ανάπτυξη ransomware, διπλός εκβιασμός, εξαγωγή δεδομένων🤖 ΜΙΤΡΑ Τακτικές, Τεχνικές & Διαδικασία T1003: Απόρριψη διαπιστευτηρίων λειτουργικού συστήματοςT1018: Απομακρυσμένη ανακάλυψη συστήματοςT1048: Exfiltration Over Alternative ProtocolT1070: Αφαίρεση ένδειξης στον κεντρικό υπολογιστήT1082: Ανακάλυψη πληροφοριών συστήματοςT1136: Δημιουργία λογαριασμούT1218: Υπογεγραμμένο δυαδικό διακομιστή μεσολάβησηςT1543: Δημιουργία ή τροποποίηση διαδικασίας συστήματοςT1560: Αρχείο Συλλεγμένων ΔεδομένωνT1590: Συλλέξτε πληροφορίες δικτύου θυμάτωνT1608: Δυνατότητες σκηνής🤬 Πρωτόκολλο Διαδικτύου209[.]141[.]43[.]37194[.]156[.]98[.]155158[.]247[.]211[.]5139[.]106[.]141[.]6847[.]117[.]165[.]166195[.]123[.]240[.]275[.]127[.]0[.]235149[.]102[.]243[.]100206[.]188[.]196[.]2051[.]81[.]42[.]234178[.]175[.]134[.]52162[.]33[.]177[.]5664[.]52[.]80[.]252162[.]33[.]178[.]196103[.]199[.]16[.]92👾 Ασφαλής Αλγόριθμος Κατακερματισμού 256-

🚀 Day 04 of my hashtag#100DaysOfCUDA challenge! 🚀1)Today I tackled a parallel partial-sum (inclusive scan) kernel on the GPU:Summed two input elements per thread (input[idx] + input[idx+blockDim.x]) into shared memory for coalesced loads.2)Added guarded-load logic so threads past the array end read zero, avoiding out-of-bounds errors.3) Laid out a tree-based inclusive scan in shared memory, doing O(log blockSize) strides with __syncthreads() for each step.4) Computed gridSize = (N + 2*blockSize – 1)/(2*blockSize) so every element is processed when each block handles 2×blockSize inputs.5)Wrapped all CUDA API calls in a CUDA_CHECK macro to catch and report errors immediately.🔹 Key takeawaysIn-place prefix sum: Implemented a scalable tree-based scan pattern in shared memory.Memory coalescing: Two-element threads maximize bandwidth by loading contiguous data.Bounds safety: Guarded-load idioms ensure correctness when N isn’t a multiple of 2×blockSize.Grid-block sizing: 2 elements per thread halves the number of required blocks, improving occupancy.📂 Check out the code and follow along: 👉 https://lnkd.in/dwkvia42Would love your feedback: 💬 Any tips for further optimizing scan kernels? 👍 Drop a like if you enjoy these daily deep dives!hashtag#CUDA hashtag#GPUProgramming hashtag#ParallelComputing hashtag#PrefixSum hashtag#SharedMemory hashtag#PMPP hashtag#100DaysOfCUDA

As a student entering the tech industry, I’ve witnessed the growing permanence of remote software engineering. What started as a pandemic workaround has evolved into a powerful model for productivity, collaboration, and inclusion.A recent GitLab Remote Work Report (2023) revealed that 86% of developers feel more productive working remotely, and 80% prefer it to in-office setups. For students, these numbers aren’t just stats—they represent opportunity. Remote work is giving us access to real-world experiences we wouldn’t otherwise have.One of my most meaningful remote experiences was developing a Unix-style shell in C, called atlas-simple_shell. This wasn’t a tutorial project—it was a fully functional command-line interpreter with features like piping, error handling, and environment variable management.What made this experience powerful wasn’t just the code—it was how my team and I collaborated. All of us were based in the same city, but none of us worked in the same place. Some preferred early mornings at the library, others coded from home or cafés late into the night. Remote work let each of us stay in our flow and schedule.We used GitHub to manage version control and pull requests, and met via Zoom when syncs were needed. Our coordination through Slack meant we could keep momentum without waiting on each other. This asynchronous setup didn’t just help the project succeed—it taught us to communicate, document, and organize like professionals.Remote collaboration doesn’t lower expectations—it raises them. Working asynchronously demands better communication, ownership, and planning. Here’s what remote professionalism meant for me:Clear Communication: Writing clean, detailed pull request messages and updates.Accountability: Sticking to deadlines, even if we weren’t being directly managed.Technical Documentation: Creating READMEs and code comments that made the project usable and understandable for everyone on the team.Collaboration Without Co-location: Knowing when to push forward independently vs. when to sync with teammates.These habits are exactly what top engineering teams need, whether remote or not.Remote software engineering has changed how students like me access experience and build skills. I didn’t need a physical internship to practice real collaboration. I learned how to handle source control in a team, maintain project structure, and debug others’ code.Even more exciting is how inclusive this model is. When location is no longer a constraint, more people can participate. Students from different backgrounds, responsibilities, and living situations can still contribute—and thrive.Remote work helped me work smarter, stay motivated, and build something meaningful with others on my own terms. It’s a practice I’m taking into the professional world with confidence.SourcesGitLab Remote Work Report 2023 – GitLabStack Overflow Blog – How Remote Engineering Teams Can Succeed

IN-OFFICE  vs  REMOTE LEGAL INTERNSHIPSYou applied for a virtual remote internship. You got selected.You updated your LinkedIn.But wait… Is a remote legal internship actually worth it?Will recruiters value it?Will you learn real skills?Orwill you just become an email-forwarding intern?Here's the verdict:1⃣ Learning curve: Hands-on work vs. Screen work📍 In-office internship = Real-world exposure. You watch senior lawyers argue in court, draft real contracts, and interact with clients. 📍 Remote internship = Good for research & drafting. But you miss out on the action. No court visits, no last-minute client calls.✅ Example: A litigation intern working in an office learns court procedures.A remote intern?They research case laws but never see them argued in real time.💡If you want practical legal skills, in-office wins. If you love research & writing, remote works.2⃣ Networking: Coffee chats vs. Cold Emails📍 In-office internship = You interact with seniors, learn from casual conversations, and build real relationships. 📍 Remote internship = You connect via emails & Zoom.It’s harder to make a lasting impression.✅ Example: An intern at a corporate firm grabs coffee with a partner, gets career advice, and later, a job referral.A remote intern?Sends a “Thank you for the opportunity” email and gets… seen-zoned.💡 Want strong industry connections? In-office internships are gold.3⃣ Work-life balance: Hustle vs. Flexibility📍 In-office internship = Fixed schedule. Long hours. Commuting stress. 📍 Remote internship = Work from anywhere. More control over time.✅ Example: A remote intern can attend classes and work at night. An in-office intern?Running from courtrooms to college like a legal Usain Bolt.💡 If you need flexibility, remote internships win. If you want the real law firm experience, in-office is unbeatable.4⃣ CV value: "Interned" vs. "Actually worked"📍 In-office internships = More credibility. Lawyers trust work done in a law firm setting. 📍 Remote internships = Skeptical recruiters.Did you really work, or just edit PDFs?✅ Example: A hiring partner sees two CVs:One intern worked physically in a top-tier firm.One intern remotely with a legal blog.Who gets the callback?You know the answer. 😉💡 Want a CV that stands out? In-office internships have more weight.5⃣ Which one teaches you more? 📍Remote internships are great for research, writing, and learning at your own pace. 📍 In-office internships teach real legal work—drafting, client handling, and actual practice.✅ Example:A litigation intern in court learns how judges react to arguments.A remote intern reads judgments but never sees them applied.💡 If you want to become a lawyer, in-office internships will teach you more.🎯 Final advice?📌 If you’re in 1st or 2nd year, remote internships help build skills. 📌 If you’re in 3rd year or beyond, prioritize in-office internships.Real exposure > Virtual learning.hashtag#law

Core JavaDay-19Encapsulation:---------------------Encapsulation is a process of making variables are private and accessing through methods public those are getters and setters.-If we declare all variables are private, then it is tightly coupled class.-If we declare any one variable is not private, then it is loosely coupled class.-setters-Always declare return type as void.-getters-Always declare its respective return type and does't have any parameter.Benefits of Encapsulation:1. Data Hiding: Encapsulation protects the data from unauthorized access.2.Increased Flexibility: It allows the internal implementation to be changed without affecting the external code.3.Improved Maintainability:  It helps in maintaining the code by keeping the data private and providing controlled access to modify it. 4.Reusability:  Encapsulated code is easier to reuse in other parts of the application.5.Testing: Encapsulated units can be tested independently.BILLA HEMANTH10000 Coders

🚀 Bare-Metal I2C LCD Project with STM32G071RBRecently completed a project interfacing a 16x2 I2C LCD (address: 0x27) with the STM32G071RB microcontroller — fully implemented using bare-metal C, without relying on HAL or any abstraction layers.🛠️ Key Technical Details:1.MCU: STM32G071RB2.I2C1 configured on PB8 (SCL) and PB9 (SDA) using Alternate Function6(AF6)3.LCD controlled via PCF8574 I/O expander4.Printed “Prathmesh” using register-level code5.Developed in STM32CubeIDE, using only core device headers🎯 Why bare-metal? This approach provides better control, efficiency, and deep understanding of hardware behavior — a crucial skill for low-level embedded systems development.💡 This project reinforced concepts like:Manual I2C protocol implementationGPIO alternate function mappingBitwise register manipulationDebugging embedded interfaces without abstraction📍Next goal: Extend this by adding sensors hashtag#EmbeddedSystems hashtag#STM32 hashtag#I2C hashtag#LCD hashtag#FirmwareDevelopment hashtag#EmbeddedC hashtag#Microcontrollers

“Are you even working if you’re not commuting 2 hours a day and eating sad sandwiches in meetings that could’ve been emails?” 😒That used to be the unspoken (and sometimes spoken) rule in the corporate world.So….Let’s rewind a bit!A few years ago, I was deep in the 9-to-5 grind. I had the desk. The ID Card. The Friday pizza parties. The “you’re on mute” calls.But also—the burnout, the lack of flexibility, and the quiet dread of Monday mornings.Remote work? That was considered a “perk,” not a viable lifestyle.It was the forbidden fruit in the orchard of productivity myths.So, I did something wild…I quit.🙃First, I dipped my toes into freelancing—scary but liberating. Then, I cannonballed into starting my own business!SynapseITSolutions !No map. Just Wi-Fi and willpower.Suddenly, I wasn’t just working remotely…I WAS LIVING INTENTIONALLY!I had control.I picked my hours, my clients, my chai breaks. I replaced commutes with creativity, and burnout with balance.And guess what?I didn’t just survive—I thrived. 😇Now here’s the kicker: the same companies that once side-eyed remote work?They’re embracing it.They’ve seen the numbers. The productivity. The morale boost. The talent retention.Turns out, trusting your team actually works. Who knew? 😉One of my favorite moments was when a former manager messaged me:“I used to think remote workers were just watching Netflix all day. Now I’m one of them—and I’ve never been more productive.”Look, remote vs hybrid vs in-office isn’t a one-size-fits-all debate.But it is about choice. Autonomy. Trust. And reimagining what work can look like!To everyone who’s made the leap, is dreaming of it, or just questioning the status quo—you’re not alone.Because work shouldn’t be a place….It should be a feeling!😇hashtag#RemoteWork hashtag#HybridWork hashtag#WorkLifeBalance hashtag#EntrepreneurLife hashtag#FreelanceLife hashtag#StartUpLife

Η επίθεση κορυφώθηκε με διπλό εκβιασμό και ανάπτυξη ransomware χρησιμοποιώντας έναν συνδυασμό κλοπής διαπιστευτηρίων, προσαρμοσμένων εμφυτευμάτων και εργαλείων απομακρυσμένου διαχειριστή.🤑 Οι Initial Access Brokers είναι συχνά το πρώτο βήμα σε μια επιτυχημένη καμπάνια για έναν παράγοντα απειλής. Οι μεσίτες πρόσβασης εργάζονται σε ένα περιβάλλον, συλλέγουν σχετικά δεδομένα και στη συνέχεια πωλούν αυτές τις πληροφορίες σε έναν παράγοντα απειλής για περαιτέρω συμβιβασμό. Ερευνητές στο Cisco Talos ανέφεραν για ένα IAB που ονομάζεται ToyMaker και παρείχαν τεχνικές λεπτομέρειες σχετικά με το προσαρμοσμένο εμφύτευμά τους που ονομάζεται LAGTOY. Η αναφορά κοινοποιεί επίσης λεπτομέρειες μιας συγκεκριμένης καμπάνιας στην οποία η ToyMaker παρείχε πρόσβαση στην ομάδα ransomware Cactus.☠️ Κακόβουλος Παράγων: ToyMaker, cactus Ransomware Group☣️ Κακόβουλο Λογισμικό: LAGTOY⚡Σοβαρότις: Υψηλή🤢 Αντίκτυπο: Κλοπή διαπιστευτηρίων, συμβιβασμός δικτύου, ανάπτυξη ransomware, διπλός εκβιασμός, εξαγωγή δεδομένων🤖 ΜΙΤΡΑ Τακτικές, Τεχνικές & Διαδικασία T1003: Απόρριψη διαπιστευτηρίων λειτουργικού συστήματοςT1018: Απομακρυσμένη ανακάλυψη συστήματοςT1048: Exfiltration Over Alternative ProtocolT1070: Αφαίρεση ένδειξης στον κεντρικό υπολογιστήT1082: Ανακάλυψη πληροφοριών συστήματοςT1136: Δημιουργία λογαριασμούT1218: Υπογεγραμμένο δυαδικό διακομιστή μεσολάβησηςT1543: Δημιουργία ή τροποποίηση διαδικασίας συστήματοςT1560: Αρχείο Συλλεγμένων ΔεδομένωνT1590: Συλλέξτε πληροφορίες δικτύου θυμάτωνT1608: Δυνατότητες σκηνής🤬 Πρωτόκολλο Διαδικτύου209[.]141[.]43[.]37194[.]156[.]98[.]155158[.]247[.]211[.]5139[.]106[.]141[.]6847[.]117[.]165[.]166195[.]123[.]240[.]275[.]127[.]0[.]235149[.]102[.]243[.]100206[.]188[.]196[.]2051[.]81[.]42[.]234178[.]175[.]134[.]52162[.]33[.]177[.]5664[.]52[.]80[.]252162[.]33[.]178[.]196103[.]199[.]16[.]92👾 Ασφαλής Αλγόριθμος Κατακερματισμού 256-

🚀 Day 04 of my hashtag#100DaysOfCUDA challenge! 🚀1)Today I tackled a parallel partial-sum (inclusive scan) kernel on the GPU:Summed two input elements per thread (input[idx] + input[idx+blockDim.x]) into shared memory for coalesced loads.2)Added guarded-load logic so threads past the array end read zero, avoiding out-of-bounds errors.3) Laid out a tree-based inclusive scan in shared memory, doing O(log blockSize) strides with __syncthreads() for each step.4) Computed gridSize = (N + 2*blockSize – 1)/(2*blockSize) so every element is processed when each block handles 2×blockSize inputs.5)Wrapped all CUDA API calls in a CUDA_CHECK macro to catch and report errors immediately.🔹 Key takeawaysIn-place prefix sum: Implemented a scalable tree-based scan pattern in shared memory.Memory coalescing: Two-element threads maximize bandwidth by loading contiguous data.Bounds safety: Guarded-load idioms ensure correctness when N isn’t a multiple of 2×blockSize.Grid-block sizing: 2 elements per thread halves the number of required blocks, improving occupancy.📂 Check out the code and follow along: 👉 https://lnkd.in/dwkvia42Would love your feedback: 💬 Any tips for further optimizing scan kernels? 👍 Drop a like if you enjoy these daily deep dives!hashtag#CUDA hashtag#GPUProgramming hashtag#ParallelComputing hashtag#PrefixSum hashtag#SharedMemory hashtag#PMPP hashtag#100DaysOfCUDA

As a student entering the tech industry, I’ve witnessed the growing permanence of remote software engineering. What started as a pandemic workaround has evolved into a powerful model for productivity, collaboration, and inclusion.A recent GitLab Remote Work Report (2023) revealed that 86% of developers feel more productive working remotely, and 80% prefer it to in-office setups. For students, these numbers aren’t just stats—they represent opportunity. Remote work is giving us access to real-world experiences we wouldn’t otherwise have.One of my most meaningful remote experiences was developing a Unix-style shell in C, called atlas-simple_shell. This wasn’t a tutorial project—it was a fully functional command-line interpreter with features like piping, error handling, and environment variable management.What made this experience powerful wasn’t just the code—it was how my team and I collaborated. All of us were based in the same city, but none of us worked in the same place. Some preferred early mornings at the library, others coded from home or cafés late into the night. Remote work let each of us stay in our flow and schedule.We used GitHub to manage version control and pull requests, and met via Zoom when syncs were needed. Our coordination through Slack meant we could keep momentum without waiting on each other. This asynchronous setup didn’t just help the project succeed—it taught us to communicate, document, and organize like professionals.Remote collaboration doesn’t lower expectations—it raises them. Working asynchronously demands better communication, ownership, and planning. Here’s what remote professionalism meant for me:Clear Communication: Writing clean, detailed pull request messages and updates.Accountability: Sticking to deadlines, even if we weren’t being directly managed.Technical Documentation: Creating READMEs and code comments that made the project usable and understandable for everyone on the team.Collaboration Without Co-location: Knowing when to push forward independently vs. when to sync with teammates.These habits are exactly what top engineering teams need, whether remote or not.Remote software engineering has changed how students like me access experience and build skills. I didn’t need a physical internship to practice real collaboration. I learned how to handle source control in a team, maintain project structure, and debug others’ code.Even more exciting is how inclusive this model is. When location is no longer a constraint, more people can participate. Students from different backgrounds, responsibilities, and living situations can still contribute—and thrive.Remote work helped me work smarter, stay motivated, and build something meaningful with others on my own terms. It’s a practice I’m taking into the professional world with confidence.SourcesGitLab Remote Work Report 2023 – GitLabStack Overflow Blog – How Remote Engineering Teams Can Succeed

IN-OFFICE  vs  REMOTE LEGAL INTERNSHIPSYou applied for a virtual remote internship. You got selected.You updated your LinkedIn.But wait… Is a remote legal internship actually worth it?Will recruiters value it?Will you learn real skills?Orwill you just become an email-forwarding intern?Here's the verdict:1⃣ Learning curve: Hands-on work vs. Screen work📍 In-office internship = Real-world exposure. You watch senior lawyers argue in court, draft real contracts, and interact with clients. 📍 Remote internship = Good for research & drafting. But you miss out on the action. No court visits, no last-minute client calls.✅ Example: A litigation intern working in an office learns court procedures.A remote intern?They research case laws but never see them argued in real time.💡If you want practical legal skills, in-office wins. If you love research & writing, remote works.2⃣ Networking: Coffee chats vs. Cold Emails📍 In-office internship = You interact with seniors, learn from casual conversations, and build real relationships. 📍 Remote internship = You connect via emails & Zoom.It’s harder to make a lasting impression.✅ Example: An intern at a corporate firm grabs coffee with a partner, gets career advice, and later, a job referral.A remote intern?Sends a “Thank you for the opportunity” email and gets… seen-zoned.💡 Want strong industry connections? In-office internships are gold.3⃣ Work-life balance: Hustle vs. Flexibility📍 In-office internship = Fixed schedule. Long hours. Commuting stress. 📍 Remote internship = Work from anywhere. More control over time.✅ Example: A remote intern can attend classes and work at night. An in-office intern?Running from courtrooms to college like a legal Usain Bolt.💡 If you need flexibility, remote internships win. If you want the real law firm experience, in-office is unbeatable.4⃣ CV value: "Interned" vs. "Actually worked"📍 In-office internships = More credibility. Lawyers trust work done in a law firm setting. 📍 Remote internships = Skeptical recruiters.Did you really work, or just edit PDFs?✅ Example: A hiring partner sees two CVs:One intern worked physically in a top-tier firm.One intern remotely with a legal blog.Who gets the callback?You know the answer. 😉💡 Want a CV that stands out? In-office internships have more weight.5⃣ Which one teaches you more? 📍Remote internships are great for research, writing, and learning at your own pace. 📍 In-office internships teach real legal work—drafting, client handling, and actual practice.✅ Example:A litigation intern in court learns how judges react to arguments.A remote intern reads judgments but never sees them applied.💡 If you want to become a lawyer, in-office internships will teach you more.🎯 Final advice?📌 If you’re in 1st or 2nd year, remote internships help build skills. 📌 If you’re in 3rd year or beyond, prioritize in-office internships.Real exposure > Virtual learning.hashtag#law

Core JavaDay-19Encapsulation:---------------------Encapsulation is a process of making variables are private and accessing through methods public those are getters and setters.-If we declare all variables are private, then it is tightly coupled class.-If we declare any one variable is not private, then it is loosely coupled class.-setters-Always declare return type as void.-getters-Always declare its respective return type and does't have any parameter.Benefits of Encapsulation:1. Data Hiding: Encapsulation protects the data from unauthorized access.2.Increased Flexibility: It allows the internal implementation to be changed without affecting the external code.3.Improved Maintainability:  It helps in maintaining the code by keeping the data private and providing controlled access to modify it. 4.Reusability:  Encapsulated code is easier to reuse in other parts of the application.5.Testing: Encapsulated units can be tested independently.BILLA HEMANTH10000 Coders

🚀 Bare-Metal I2C LCD Project with STM32G071RBRecently completed a project interfacing a 16x2 I2C LCD (address: 0x27) with the STM32G071RB microcontroller — fully implemented using bare-metal C, without relying on HAL or any abstraction layers.🛠️ Key Technical Details:1.MCU: STM32G071RB2.I2C1 configured on PB8 (SCL) and PB9 (SDA) using Alternate Function6(AF6)3.LCD controlled via PCF8574 I/O expander4.Printed “Prathmesh” using register-level code5.Developed in STM32CubeIDE, using only core device headers🎯 Why bare-metal? This approach provides better control, efficiency, and deep understanding of hardware behavior — a crucial skill for low-level embedded systems development.💡 This project reinforced concepts like:Manual I2C protocol implementationGPIO alternate function mappingBitwise register manipulationDebugging embedded interfaces without abstraction📍Next goal: Extend this by adding sensors hashtag#EmbeddedSystems hashtag#STM32 hashtag#I2C hashtag#LCD hashtag#FirmwareDevelopment hashtag#EmbeddedC hashtag#Microcontrollers

“Are you even working if you’re not commuting 2 hours a day and eating sad sandwiches in meetings that could’ve been emails?” 😒That used to be the unspoken (and sometimes spoken) rule in the corporate world.So….Let’s rewind a bit!A few years ago, I was deep in the 9-to-5 grind. I had the desk. The ID Card. The Friday pizza parties. The “you’re on mute” calls.But also—the burnout, the lack of flexibility, and the quiet dread of Monday mornings.Remote work? That was considered a “perk,” not a viable lifestyle.It was the forbidden fruit in the orchard of productivity myths.So, I did something wild…I quit.🙃First, I dipped my toes into freelancing—scary but liberating. Then, I cannonballed into starting my own business!SynapseITSolutions !No map. Just Wi-Fi and willpower.Suddenly, I wasn’t just working remotely…I WAS LIVING INTENTIONALLY!I had control.I picked my hours, my clients, my chai breaks. I replaced commutes with creativity, and burnout with balance.And guess what?I didn’t just survive—I thrived. 😇Now here’s the kicker: the same companies that once side-eyed remote work?They’re embracing it.They’ve seen the numbers. The productivity. The morale boost. The talent retention.Turns out, trusting your team actually works. Who knew? 😉One of my favorite moments was when a former manager messaged me:“I used to think remote workers were just watching Netflix all day. Now I’m one of them—and I’ve never been more productive.”Look, remote vs hybrid vs in-office isn’t a one-size-fits-all debate.But it is about choice. Autonomy. Trust. And reimagining what work can look like!To everyone who’s made the leap, is dreaming of it, or just questioning the status quo—you’re not alone.Because work shouldn’t be a place….It should be a feeling!😇hashtag#RemoteWork hashtag#HybridWork hashtag#WorkLifeBalance hashtag#EntrepreneurLife hashtag#FreelanceLife hashtag#StartUpLife

🚀 Day 04 of my hashtag#100DaysOfCUDA challenge! 🚀1)Today I tackled a parallel partial-sum (inclusive scan) kernel on the GPU:Summed two input elements per thread (input[idx] + input[idx+blockDim.x]) into shared memory for coalesced loads.2)Added guarded-load logic so threads past the array end read zero, avoiding out-of-bounds errors.3) Laid out a tree-based inclusive scan in shared memory, doing O(log blockSize) strides with __syncthreads() for each step.4) Computed gridSize = (N + 2*blockSize – 1)/(2*blockSize) so every element is processed when each block handles 2×blockSize inputs.5)Wrapped all CUDA API calls in a CUDA_CHECK macro to catch and report errors immediately.🔹 Key takeawaysIn-place prefix sum: Implemented a scalable tree-based scan pattern in shared memory.Memory coalescing: Two-element threads maximize bandwidth by loading contiguous data.Bounds safety: Guarded-load idioms ensure correctness when N isn’t a multiple of 2×blockSize.Grid-block sizing: 2 elements per thread halves the number of required blocks, improving occupancy.📂 Check out the code and follow along: 👉 https://lnkd.in/dwkvia42Would love your feedback: 💬 Any tips for further optimizing scan kernels? 👍 Drop a like if you enjoy these daily deep dives!hashtag#CUDA hashtag#GPUProgramming hashtag#ParallelComputing hashtag#PrefixSum hashtag#SharedMemory hashtag#PMPP hashtag#100DaysOfCUDA

As a student entering the tech industry, I’ve witnessed the growing permanence of remote software engineering. What started as a pandemic workaround has evolved into a powerful model for productivity, collaboration, and inclusion.A recent GitLab Remote Work Report (2023) revealed that 86% of developers feel more productive working remotely, and 80% prefer it to in-office setups. For students, these numbers aren’t just stats—they represent opportunity. Remote work is giving us access to real-world experiences we wouldn’t otherwise have.One of my most meaningful remote experiences was developing a Unix-style shell in C, called atlas-simple_shell. This wasn’t a tutorial project—it was a fully functional command-line interpreter with features like piping, error handling, and environment variable management.What made this experience powerful wasn’t just the code—it was how my team and I collaborated. All of us were based in the same city, but none of us worked in the same place. Some preferred early mornings at the library, others coded from home or cafés late into the night. Remote work let each of us stay in our flow and schedule.We used GitHub to manage version control and pull requests, and met via Zoom when syncs were needed. Our coordination through Slack meant we could keep momentum without waiting on each other. This asynchronous setup didn’t just help the project succeed—it taught us to communicate, document, and organize like professionals.Remote collaboration doesn’t lower expectations—it raises them. Working asynchronously demands better communication, ownership, and planning. Here’s what remote professionalism meant for me:Clear Communication: Writing clean, detailed pull request messages and updates.Accountability: Sticking to deadlines, even if we weren’t being directly managed.Technical Documentation: Creating READMEs and code comments that made the project usable and understandable for everyone on the team.Collaboration Without Co-location: Knowing when to push forward independently vs. when to sync with teammates.These habits are exactly what top engineering teams need, whether remote or not.Remote software engineering has changed how students like me access experience and build skills. I didn’t need a physical internship to practice real collaboration. I learned how to handle source control in a team, maintain project structure, and debug others’ code.Even more exciting is how inclusive this model is. When location is no longer a constraint, more people can participate. Students from different backgrounds, responsibilities, and living situations can still contribute—and thrive.Remote work helped me work smarter, stay motivated, and build something meaningful with others on my own terms. It’s a practice I’m taking into the professional world with confidence.SourcesGitLab Remote Work Report 2023 – GitLabStack Overflow Blog – How Remote Engineering Teams Can Succeed

IN-OFFICE  vs  REMOTE LEGAL INTERNSHIPSYou applied for a virtual remote internship. You got selected.You updated your LinkedIn.But wait… Is a remote legal internship actually worth it?Will recruiters value it?Will you learn real skills?Orwill you just become an email-forwarding intern?Here's the verdict:1⃣ Learning curve: Hands-on work vs. Screen work📍 In-office internship = Real-world exposure. You watch senior lawyers argue in court, draft real contracts, and interact with clients. 📍 Remote internship = Good for research & drafting. But you miss out on the action. No court visits, no last-minute client calls.✅ Example: A litigation intern working in an office learns court procedures.A remote intern?They research case laws but never see them argued in real time.💡If you want practical legal skills, in-office wins. If you love research & writing, remote works.2⃣ Networking: Coffee chats vs. Cold Emails📍 In-office internship = You interact with seniors, learn from casual conversations, and build real relationships. 📍 Remote internship = You connect via emails & Zoom.It’s harder to make a lasting impression.✅ Example: An intern at a corporate firm grabs coffee with a partner, gets career advice, and later, a job referral.A remote intern?Sends a “Thank you for the opportunity” email and gets… seen-zoned.💡 Want strong industry connections? In-office internships are gold.3⃣ Work-life balance: Hustle vs. Flexibility📍 In-office internship = Fixed schedule. Long hours. Commuting stress. 📍 Remote internship = Work from anywhere. More control over time.✅ Example: A remote intern can attend classes and work at night. An in-office intern?Running from courtrooms to college like a legal Usain Bolt.💡 If you need flexibility, remote internships win. If you want the real law firm experience, in-office is unbeatable.4⃣ CV value: "Interned" vs. "Actually worked"📍 In-office internships = More credibility. Lawyers trust work done in a law firm setting. 📍 Remote internships = Skeptical recruiters.Did you really work, or just edit PDFs?✅ Example: A hiring partner sees two CVs:One intern worked physically in a top-tier firm.One intern remotely with a legal blog.Who gets the callback?You know the answer. 😉💡 Want a CV that stands out? In-office internships have more weight.5⃣ Which one teaches you more? 📍Remote internships are great for research, writing, and learning at your own pace. 📍 In-office internships teach real legal work—drafting, client handling, and actual practice.✅ Example:A litigation intern in court learns how judges react to arguments.A remote intern reads judgments but never sees them applied.💡 If you want to become a lawyer, in-office internships will teach you more.🎯 Final advice?📌 If you’re in 1st or 2nd year, remote internships help build skills. 📌 If you’re in 3rd year or beyond, prioritize in-office internships.Real exposure > Virtual learning.hashtag#law

Core JavaDay-19Encapsulation:---------------------Encapsulation is a process of making variables are private and accessing through methods public those are getters and setters.-If we declare all variables are private, then it is tightly coupled class.-If we declare any one variable is not private, then it is loosely coupled class.-setters-Always declare return type as void.-getters-Always declare its respective return type and does't have any parameter.Benefits of Encapsulation:1. Data Hiding: Encapsulation protects the data from unauthorized access.2.Increased Flexibility: It allows the internal implementation to be changed without affecting the external code.3.Improved Maintainability:  It helps in maintaining the code by keeping the data private and providing controlled access to modify it. 4.Reusability:  Encapsulated code is easier to reuse in other parts of the application.5.Testing: Encapsulated units can be tested independently.BILLA HEMANTH10000 Coders

“Are you even working if you’re not commuting 2 hours a day and eating sad sandwiches in meetings that could’ve been emails?” 😒That used to be the unspoken (and sometimes spoken) rule in the corporate world.So….Let’s rewind a bit!A few years ago, I was deep in the 9-to-5 grind. I had the desk. The ID Card. The Friday pizza parties. The “you’re on mute” calls.But also—the burnout, the lack of flexibility, and the quiet dread of Monday mornings.Remote work? That was considered a “perk,” not a viable lifestyle.It was the forbidden fruit in the orchard of productivity myths.So, I did something wild…I quit.🙃First, I dipped my toes into freelancing—scary but liberating. Then, I cannonballed into starting my own business!SynapseITSolutions !No map. Just Wi-Fi and willpower.Suddenly, I wasn’t just working remotely…I WAS LIVING INTENTIONALLY!I had control.I picked my hours, my clients, my chai breaks. I replaced commutes with creativity, and burnout with balance.And guess what?I didn’t just survive—I thrived. 😇Now here’s the kicker: the same companies that once side-eyed remote work?They’re embracing it.They’ve seen the numbers. The productivity. The morale boost. The talent retention.Turns out, trusting your team actually works. Who knew? 😉One of my favorite moments was when a former manager messaged me:“I used to think remote workers were just watching Netflix all day. Now I’m one of them—and I’ve never been more productive.”Look, remote vs hybrid vs in-office isn’t a one-size-fits-all debate.But it is about choice. Autonomy. Trust. And reimagining what work can look like!To everyone who’s made the leap, is dreaming of it, or just questioning the status quo—you’re not alone.Because work shouldn’t be a place….It should be a feeling!😇hashtag#RemoteWork hashtag#HybridWork hashtag#WorkLifeBalance hashtag#EntrepreneurLife hashtag#FreelanceLife hashtag#StartUpLife

🚀 Day 04 of my hashtag#100DaysOfCUDA challenge! 🚀1)Today I tackled a parallel partial-sum (inclusive scan) kernel on the GPU:Summed two input elements per thread (input[idx] + input[idx+blockDim.x]) into shared memory for coalesced loads.2)Added guarded-load logic so threads past the array end read zero, avoiding out-of-bounds errors.3) Laid out a tree-based inclusive scan in shared memory, doing O(log blockSize) strides with __syncthreads() for each step.4) Computed gridSize = (N + 2*blockSize – 1)/(2*blockSize) so every element is processed when each block handles 2×blockSize inputs.5)Wrapped all CUDA API calls in a CUDA_CHECK macro to catch and report errors immediately.🔹 Key takeawaysIn-place prefix sum: Implemented a scalable tree-based scan pattern in shared memory.Memory coalescing: Two-element threads maximize bandwidth by loading contiguous data.Bounds safety: Guarded-load idioms ensure correctness when N isn’t a multiple of 2×blockSize.Grid-block sizing: 2 elements per thread halves the number of required blocks, improving occupancy.📂 Check out the code and follow along: 👉 https://lnkd.in/dwkvia42Would love your feedback: 💬 Any tips for further optimizing scan kernels? 👍 Drop a like if you enjoy these daily deep dives!hashtag#CUDA hashtag#GPUProgramming hashtag#ParallelComputing hashtag#PrefixSum hashtag#SharedMemory hashtag#PMPP hashtag#100DaysOfCUDA

As a student entering the tech industry, I’ve witnessed the growing permanence of remote software engineering. What started as a pandemic workaround has evolved into a powerful model for productivity, collaboration, and inclusion.A recent GitLab Remote Work Report (2023) revealed that 86% of developers feel more productive working remotely, and 80% prefer it to in-office setups. For students, these numbers aren’t just stats—they represent opportunity. Remote work is giving us access to real-world experiences we wouldn’t otherwise have.One of my most meaningful remote experiences was developing a Unix-style shell in C, called atlas-simple_shell. This wasn’t a tutorial project—it was a fully functional command-line interpreter with features like piping, error handling, and environment variable management.What made this experience powerful wasn’t just the code—it was how my team and I collaborated. All of us were based in the same city, but none of us worked in the same place. Some preferred early mornings at the library, others coded from home or cafés late into the night. Remote work let each of us stay in our flow and schedule.We used GitHub to manage version control and pull requests, and met via Zoom when syncs were needed. Our coordination through Slack meant we could keep momentum without waiting on each other. This asynchronous setup didn’t just help the project succeed—it taught us to communicate, document, and organize like professionals.Remote collaboration doesn’t lower expectations—it raises them. Working asynchronously demands better communication, ownership, and planning. Here’s what remote professionalism meant for me:Clear Communication: Writing clean, detailed pull request messages and updates.Accountability: Sticking to deadlines, even if we weren’t being directly managed.Technical Documentation: Creating READMEs and code comments that made the project usable and understandable for everyone on the team.Collaboration Without Co-location: Knowing when to push forward independently vs. when to sync with teammates.These habits are exactly what top engineering teams need, whether remote or not.Remote software engineering has changed how students like me access experience and build skills. I didn’t need a physical internship to practice real collaboration. I learned how to handle source control in a team, maintain project structure, and debug others’ code.Even more exciting is how inclusive this model is. When location is no longer a constraint, more people can participate. Students from different backgrounds, responsibilities, and living situations can still contribute—and thrive.Remote work helped me work smarter, stay motivated, and build something meaningful with others on my own terms. It’s a practice I’m taking into the professional world with confidence.SourcesGitLab Remote Work Report 2023 – GitLabStack Overflow Blog – How Remote Engineering Teams Can Succeed

Some thoughts on hashtag#remoteWorkI don’t think I need to explain how remote work has evolved in recent years. Before COVID-19 (pre-2021), remote work was a rare privilege—something only a lucky few could negotiate. But during the pandemic, it became the norm, especially in computer-based fields like software engineering, analytics, and marketing.Over the past few months, however, we've seen increasing pushback. Some companies have gone as far as mandating a full return to the office—not just hybrid, but five days a week. I wanted to reflect on what feels like a regression.I call it a regression because, had it not been for a global pandemic, many companies would still believe that productivity could only be guaranteed through physical presence—by clocking in and out, sitting at a desk under watchful eyes. But we proved otherwise. Productivity didn’t tank. The world didn’t stop. The sun didn’t rise from the west.That said, remote work wasn’t without its challenges. Some individuals abused the flexibility—juggling multiple full-time roles at once and damaging the trust-based relationship needed for remote work to thrive.I’ve also noticed that some recent graduates, who entered the workforce in this new remote-first world, struggled with engagement. Thrust into what felt like a dream scenario, some lacked the structure or mentorship that in-person environments naturally provide—leading to performance issues.But let’s not allow a few bad examples to overshadow the bigger picture. Remote work may be one of the greatest professional shifts of our time. At least for me, here’s what it’s meant:1.  I gained back over 2 hours a day from commuting—that’s 700 hours a year. Less commuting = less stress and wasted energy = more productivity.2. That’s time I now spend with my family, myself—or yes, sometimes, even working.3. Most importantly, I got to watch my baby girl grow up. Every day. From the moment she was born until now, two years later, I’ve seen her in her element. That’s priceless. It’s something many of our fathers missed—and I don’t think we should repeat that mistake.4. I have more control over my timSo how do we make remote work a win-win?1. Trust, but verify: Build accountability through regular check-ins, clear deliverables, and performance metrics.2. Hybrid mentorship: Pair remote flexibility with in-person or virtual mentorship to support junior talent.3. Cultural investment: Create intentional moments for team bonding and alignment—digitally or otherwise.4. Results over hours: Focus on outcomes, not desk time. Empower employees to own their time.Remote work isn’t perfect—but neither was the old way. Let’s not lose sight of the enormous good it can bring, when done right. I’m genuinely grateful to Klarna for embracing this culture—striking a healthy balance between drive and productivity, while honoring the importance of family and well-being. Let’s evolve, not revert.hashtag#remotework hashtag#futureofwork hashtag#productivity

IN-OFFICE  vs  REMOTE LEGAL INTERNSHIPSYou applied for a virtual remote internship. You got selected.You updated your LinkedIn.But wait… Is a remote legal internship actually worth it?Will recruiters value it?Will you learn real skills?Orwill you just become an email-forwarding intern?Here's the verdict:1⃣ Learning curve: Hands-on work vs. Screen work📍 In-office internship = Real-world exposure. You watch senior lawyers argue in court, draft real contracts, and interact with clients. 📍 Remote internship = Good for research & drafting. But you miss out on the action. No court visits, no last-minute client calls.✅ Example: A litigation intern working in an office learns court procedures.A remote intern?They research case laws but never see them argued in real time.💡If you want practical legal skills, in-office wins. If you love research & writing, remote works.2⃣ Networking: Coffee chats vs. Cold Emails📍 In-office internship = You interact with seniors, learn from casual conversations, and build real relationships. 📍 Remote internship = You connect via emails & Zoom.It’s harder to make a lasting impression.✅ Example: An intern at a corporate firm grabs coffee with a partner, gets career advice, and later, a job referral.A remote intern?Sends a “Thank you for the opportunity” email and gets… seen-zoned.💡 Want strong industry connections? In-office internships are gold.3⃣ Work-life balance: Hustle vs. Flexibility📍 In-office internship = Fixed schedule. Long hours. Commuting stress. 📍 Remote internship = Work from anywhere. More control over time.✅ Example: A remote intern can attend classes and work at night. An in-office intern?Running from courtrooms to college like a legal Usain Bolt.💡 If you need flexibility, remote internships win. If you want the real law firm experience, in-office is unbeatable.4⃣ CV value: "Interned" vs. "Actually worked"📍 In-office internships = More credibility. Lawyers trust work done in a law firm setting. 📍 Remote internships = Skeptical recruiters.Did you really work, or just edit PDFs?✅ Example: A hiring partner sees two CVs:One intern worked physically in a top-tier firm.One intern remotely with a legal blog.Who gets the callback?You know the answer. 😉💡 Want a CV that stands out? In-office internships have more weight.5⃣ Which one teaches you more? 📍Remote internships are great for research, writing, and learning at your own pace. 📍 In-office internships teach real legal work—drafting, client handling, and actual practice.✅ Example:A litigation intern in court learns how judges react to arguments.A remote intern reads judgments but never sees them applied.💡 If you want to become a lawyer, in-office internships will teach you more.🎯 Final advice?📌 If you’re in 1st or 2nd year, remote internships help build skills. 📌 If you’re in 3rd year or beyond, prioritize in-office internships.Real exposure > Virtual learning.hashtag#law

Core JavaDay-19Encapsulation:---------------------Encapsulation is a process of making variables are private and accessing through methods public those are getters and setters.-If we declare all variables are private, then it is tightly coupled class.-If we declare any one variable is not private, then it is loosely coupled class.-setters-Always declare return type as void.-getters-Always declare its respective return type and does't have any parameter.Benefits of Encapsulation:1. Data Hiding: Encapsulation protects the data from unauthorized access.2.Increased Flexibility: It allows the internal implementation to be changed without affecting the external code.3.Improved Maintainability:  It helps in maintaining the code by keeping the data private and providing controlled access to modify it. 4.Reusability:  Encapsulated code is easier to reuse in other parts of the application.5.Testing: Encapsulated units can be tested independently.BILLA HEMANTH10000 Coders

“Are you even working if you’re not commuting 2 hours a day and eating sad sandwiches in meetings that could’ve been emails?” 😒That used to be the unspoken (and sometimes spoken) rule in the corporate world.So….Let’s rewind a bit!A few years ago, I was deep in the 9-to-5 grind. I had the desk. The ID Card. The Friday pizza parties. The “you’re on mute” calls.But also—the burnout, the lack of flexibility, and the quiet dread of Monday mornings.Remote work? That was considered a “perk,” not a viable lifestyle.It was the forbidden fruit in the orchard of productivity myths.So, I did something wild…I quit.🙃First, I dipped my toes into freelancing—scary but liberating. Then, I cannonballed into starting my own business!SynapseITSolutions !No map. Just Wi-Fi and willpower.Suddenly, I wasn’t just working remotely…I WAS LIVING INTENTIONALLY!I had control.I picked my hours, my clients, my chai breaks. I replaced commutes with creativity, and burnout with balance.And guess what?I didn’t just survive—I thrived. 😇Now here’s the kicker: the same companies that once side-eyed remote work?They’re embracing it.They’ve seen the numbers. The productivity. The morale boost. The talent retention.Turns out, trusting your team actually works. Who knew? 😉One of my favorite moments was when a former manager messaged me:“I used to think remote workers were just watching Netflix all day. Now I’m one of them—and I’ve never been more productive.”Look, remote vs hybrid vs in-office isn’t a one-size-fits-all debate.But it is about choice. Autonomy. Trust. And reimagining what work can look like!To everyone who’s made the leap, is dreaming of it, or just questioning the status quo—you’re not alone.Because work shouldn’t be a place….It should be a feeling!😇hashtag#RemoteWork hashtag#HybridWork hashtag#WorkLifeBalance hashtag#EntrepreneurLife hashtag#FreelanceLife hashtag#StartUpLife

🚀 Day 04 of my hashtag#100DaysOfCUDA challenge! 🚀1)Today I tackled a parallel partial-sum (inclusive scan) kernel on the GPU:Summed two input elements per thread (input[idx] + input[idx+blockDim.x]) into shared memory for coalesced loads.2)Added guarded-load logic so threads past the array end read zero, avoiding out-of-bounds errors.3) Laid out a tree-based inclusive scan in shared memory, doing O(log blockSize) strides with __syncthreads() for each step.4) Computed gridSize = (N + 2*blockSize – 1)/(2*blockSize) so every element is processed when each block handles 2×blockSize inputs.5)Wrapped all CUDA API calls in a CUDA_CHECK macro to catch and report errors immediately.🔹 Key takeawaysIn-place prefix sum: Implemented a scalable tree-based scan pattern in shared memory.Memory coalescing: Two-element threads maximize bandwidth by loading contiguous data.Bounds safety: Guarded-load idioms ensure correctness when N isn’t a multiple of 2×blockSize.Grid-block sizing: 2 elements per thread halves the number of required blocks, improving occupancy.📂 Check out the code and follow along: 👉 https://lnkd.in/dwkvia42Would love your feedback: 💬 Any tips for further optimizing scan kernels? 👍 Drop a like if you enjoy these daily deep dives!hashtag#CUDA hashtag#GPUProgramming hashtag#ParallelComputing hashtag#PrefixSum hashtag#SharedMemory hashtag#PMPP hashtag#100DaysOfCUDA
